author: sky.cactus
content: <@486501030046203915> What are your thoughts on the current `1/8` change per block?  It *feels* like there is more volatility than desirable at the moment, and I wonder if slowing the rate of change would help smooth that out.

author: barnabemonnot
content:
I should have shared here before but we recently released a paper on the 1559 update rule: https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.04753

generally our conclusion is that 1/8 does a slower than desired ramp up during market events and indeed more volatility than desirable during market stability. we suggest an adaptive learning rate that navigates this trade-off better. atm we are trying to validate this update rule against other options with historical data (there is a bit of that already in the paper but we have a better methodology now)

so my thoughts is rather than tweaking the parameter only, i'd rather see a more comprehensive update to the update rule. maybe that could be part of a package of upgrades that includes <@!415548822983278593> 's time-aware basefee rule too

author: jgm
content:
This is a very old argument.  This issue with Bitcoin is that it runs out of funds to pay for block security, relying on transaction fees to take up the strain.  This is a complete unknown in the years to come, so long-term security of the chain cannot be guaranteed.  By issuing new Ether the chain provides a much stronger guarantee of security ad infinitum, and with burning there is a balancing force to reduce total supply.

It's always possible that Ether total supply ends up decreasing rapidly, but there is no immediate harm in that and can be addressed over a much longer timescale (_i.e._ years) if desired.  A fixed schedule, however, is not the way to go as we end up with the same problem as Bitcoin.

(And yes this isn't really the place to talk about this so I'll shut up.)
